items.name: Ionian Mode
items.description: The first mode of the major scale, also known as the major scale itself.
items.details: The Ionian mode is the foundation of Western music. It has a bright, happy, and resolved character. Pattern: W-W-H-W-W-W-H. This is the mode you play when you play a major scale starting and ending on the root.
examples: Used extensively in pop, classical, and all major-key music

items.name: Dorian Mode
items.description: The second mode of the major scale, with a minor quality but raised 6th degree.
items.details: The Dorian mode sounds minor but brighter than natural minor. Pattern: W-H-W-W-W-H-W. It's the second mode built from any major scale. Used extensively in jazz, funk, and rock.
examples: Common in jazz solos and funk grooves

items.name: Phrygian Mode
items.description: The third mode of the major scale, with Spanish or Middle Eastern flavor.
items.details: The Phrygian mode has an exotic, dark quality with a raised 2nd degree. Pattern: H-W-W-W-H-W-W. Creates a mysterious, sometimes ominous sound. Popular in flamenco and metal.
examples: Essential in flamenco, Spanish guitar, and extreme metal

items.name: Lydian Mode
items.description: The fourth mode of the major scale, with a raised 4th degree.
items.details: The Lydian mode sounds major but dreamy and ethereal with an augmented 4th. Pattern: W-W-W-H-W-W-H. Often described as 'ethereal' or 'dreamy'. Popular in film scores and progressive rock.
examples: Used in film scores, fantasy music, and progressive rock

items.name: Mixolydian Mode
items.description: The fifth mode of the major scale, with a lowered 7th degree (blues note).
items.details: The Mixolydian mode sounds major but bluesy with a flattened 7th. Pattern: W-W-H-W-W-H-W. Creates a major but unresolved, bluesy quality. Very common in rock and blues.
examples: Essential in blues, rock, funk, and many pop songs

items.name: Aeolian Mode
items.description: The sixth mode of the major scale, also known as the natural minor scale.
items.details: The Aeolian mode is the natural minor scale. Pattern: W-H-W-W-H-W-W. Sounds sad or introspective. One of the most used scales in all music after the major scale.
examples: Used universally in minor-key music across all genres

items.name: Locrian Mode
items.description: The seventh mode of the major scale, with a flat 2nd and flat 5th.
items.details: The Locrian mode is the darkest and most unstable mode. Pattern: H-W-W-H-W-W-W. Rarely used but creates an unsettling, dissonant quality. Found in progressive rock, metal, and experimental music.
examples: Uncommon, used for special effects and dark moods
